Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Biomimetic Nanostructured Semiconductors for Controlled Electrical Interfacing with Single Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Career award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to the University of Chicago is to investigate the fundamental limits of signal transduction at the interface between biological cells and inorganic materials. The objectives of this proposal are to investigate the effect of surface morphology and chemistry of nanoscale semiconductors on their structural and electrical interfaces with mammalian cells. The proposed study will potentially yield a new biomaterials platform for conducting electrical recording of single cell activities, which will have much higher spatiotemporal resolutions and better signal to noise ratio than conventional fluorescence or microelectrode based techniques. This work will adopt an integrative approach involving experiments in materials chemistry, biophysics and cell biology. The materials and devices proposed in this work can potentially yield highly sensitive devices for biomedical applications. As part of this Career award, an integrated educational goal is proposed to create a research-intensive learning environment to educate students on subjects of nanostructured semiconductors, biomaterials and biophysics. Based on research results, educational materials, demonstrations, and web tutorials will be developed. Existing model programs at the University of Chicago will be used to increase diversity in science and engineering by offering summer research opportunities to high school and undergraduate students. Finally, two international summer exchange programs are being launched that will allow the undergraduate and graduate students to work with collaborators in China or Israel.

Electrical signals from single cells can regulate their functioning. Earlier studies by this investigator have shown that these signals can be measured using nanoscale materials and devices. The proposed research is to gain a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms by which nanoscale materials and devices record these electrical activities. This work plans to adopt an integrative approach involving experiments in materials chemistry, biophysics and cell biology. The materials and devices proposed in this work can potentially yield highly sensitive devices for biomedical applications. The research activities will provide learning opportunities for students in a highly interdisciplinary research environment. The study will also provide a unique knowledge and skill set that can open new areas of endeavor in the semiconductor or detector industry. In addition to existing outreach programs at the University of Chicago, overseas studies in China or Israel will be planned to provide the US students with an awareness and lifelong appreciation of scientists and engineers in other countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research goal for this NSF CAREER award (ID:1254637) was to understand the fundamental limits of signal transduction at the interface between biological cells/organelles and inorganic materials. The objectives of this work were to investigate mechanisms by which the nanoscale topography and other physical properties of nanostructured semiconductors enhance the electrical interfaces with mammalian cells, and, beyond that, the potential of using these new semiconductors as biomaterials for electrical cellular studies at the single cell and sub-cellular level. My educational goal was to create a research-intensive learning environment to educate students on subjects of nanostructured semiconductors, biomaterials and biophysics. Based on research results, I have developed educational materials, and demonstrations. I have integrated them into graduate and upper-level undergraduate physical chemistry and materials research courses to deepen students' understanding of the course fundamentals. Additionally, the research has provided me opportunities to attract and nurture diverse future scientists to work at the biophysical frontiers of semiconductors. Finally, the proposed research has allowed students access to the first University-owned, multi-user cleanroom facility for semiconductor processing.   

Intellectual merits: Our research integrates materials science with biophysics, and has made unique contributions in three areas: (1) enabling non-genetic, freestanding and semiconductor-based biological modulation, (2) revealing new dynamic aspects of metal in extracellular matrix-like semiconductor synthesis, and (3) exploring dynamic behaviors of minerals in polymeric matrices for semiconductor-based bioelectronics. During the award period, our group at UChicago has produced multiple manuscripts as the primary contributors, including one in Science (Luo et al., 2015), on in Nature Materials (Jiang et al., 2016), one in Nature Nanotechnology (Parameswaran et al., 2018), one in Nature Biomedical Engineering (Jiang et al., 2018), two in Nature Communications (Yi et al. and Fang et al., 2017), one in Science Advances (Zimmerman et al., 2016), and multiple review articles. Additionally, we have filed a patent.

Broader impacts: The research activities have provided learning opportunities for students in a highly interdisciplinary area. The team members have received multiple distinguished awards and honors, including Mr. Harrison Wang’s Gold medal at the 49th International Chemistry Olympiad in 2017 summer. Many students have significantly advanced their career development, and entered top schools such as Harvard, MIT, Stanford, and Caltech for college/graduate school studies and postdoc research. The proposed study has provided a unique knowledge and skill set that opened new areas of endeavor in the semiconductor or detector industry. We have also built on existing model programs at the University of Chicago to increase diversity in science and engineering by offering summer research opportunities to high school and undergraduate students. In addition, one international summer exchange program was launched that allowed the undergraduate student to visit Professor Ying Fang’s research group at the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology and other places in China. The mixing of cultures and backgrounds during overseas study has provided the US student with an unforgettable awareness and lifelong appreciation of scientists and engineers in China. Moreover, the cellular interface materials studied in this work have yielded highly efficient biomedical devices for translational studies especially in cardiovascular disease and neurodegenerative disorders. Finally, the research and education results have been disseminated broadly through peer-reviewed publications, seminars, conference presentations, and websites.
